posts.com: Hi all, I got a food dehydrator for my birthday a few months ago. I have made several batches that taste good, but they never have the consistency and mouth feel of store bought jerky. So I am asking what I'm doing wrong? My process is to take the meat, let it sit in a marinade for 4-12 hours, then dehydrate for 8-12 hours. The meat usually tastes good, but it's way more tough than store bought. Is there a step or a chemical component I'm missing? Pic related it's beef jerky on top of some spam I tried to jerky based off a YouTube video. (The Spam jerky wasn't bad.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18742116
Youll probably never get the consistency of commercial jerky but pineapple juice in the marinade and marinating for way longer will help
I usually do about a week

posts.name: Failmcweaksaws
posts.com:
>>18742148
Just so I understand, you marinade for an entire week? I can understand how that can break down the protein and make it more tender but don't you run the risk of it going bad?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18742116
After you cut the strips, mix them with some bicarbonate of soda for ten to fifteen minutes, rinse well, then marinade. The bicarbonate sets the protein. You don’t need quite as much time in the dehydrator as the meat is effectively already ‘cured’ chemically.

>>18737418
Bugs are not a viable alternative protein source for humans for several reasons. First, the human body cannot digest chitin, the main component of insect exoskeletons. Second, bugs are not a very efficient source of protein, requiring more food (in the form of insects) to convert into protein than other animals such as chickens

There are a number of reasons why the human body cannot digest chitin. Chitin is a complex polysaccharide that is not broken down by human digestive enzymes. Additionally, chitin is not a good source of nutrition for humans, as it is not a good source of essential amino acids. Finally, chitin can actually have a negative impact on human health, as it can bind to and kill beneficial gut bacteria

Bugs are also not a very efficient source of protein. In order to obtain usable protein from bugs, humans would need to eat a large number of them. This is because insects are mostly made up of exoskeleton, which is indigestible for humans. Additionally, insects have a very low conversion rate of food to protein, meaning that more insects would need to be eaten to obtain the same amount of protein as from other animals

Finally, bugs are a significant source of greenhouse gas emissions. A study published in the journal Science found that a diet rich in insects would result in higher emissions of methane and nitrous oxide, two of the most potent greenhouse gases. The study found that the emissions from a diet of insects were about double those of a typical livestock-based diet.

Source:
htps://www.scientificamerican.com/article/sorry-entomophagy-fans-eating-insects-is-not-sustainable/
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0271531711003073
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3709646/

posts.com:
>>18703613
I don't like:

1) Processed cheese. Anyone who puts processsed cheese on a burger should get a firing squad. Unless you're a wagie at a fast food place, there are no excuses for doing this shit, ever.

2) Fried eggs. The sulfur taste of the yolk and the texture of the eggs clashes with the rest. If you made a thin omelette and folded it and put it on the burger that could work for a breakfast burger, but that's about the only reason I can think of.

3) Olives, marinated artichokes or pickled peppers: They're fucking great, especially in sandwiches, but they're too wet and don't pair well with other ingredients.

4) Any kind of weird shit mixed into the ground beef used to make the burger patties. The beef should contain only beef, and perhaps salt. MAYBE you can add black pepper. MAYBE. If the beef is getting old then crust it in garlic powder to mask the taste a bit, but that's only if the beef is on the edge of inedible. Don't drown it in a ton of butter or oil. Put the patties in a little oil to start with, but let them cook in their own fat.

5) Non-western spices/ingredients. Anyone who adds weird goop like gookchang should be given a free helicopter ride.

6) Excessive grease or sauce. I don't like a slimy burger, fuck off with that shit.

7) Fake meat. I don't need to say anything else.
A burger can contain any kind of meat, but it should have meat. Not sure what to call Portobello burgers.

8) Foods which are generally incompatible with the structure of a burger, or which don't pair with burgers well. Overly sweet things, for example. So, no donuts or strudels.

I can't think of anything else, is that a good list?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When I started making burgers at home I realised how little you actually need to make a good burger.
Lots of toppings just overcrowds a burger, makes it sloppy and unstable, you honestly just need 1 strongly flavoured topping.
My top is:
- jalapenos
- pickles (salt ones not vinegar)
- olives (green)
- NO KETCHUP, literally anything is better, I usually like weird shit like remoulade, but even mayo or a generic burger sauce is better than ketchup.
I don't even use cheese sometimes because i can't even taste it in the burger. Unless i use something strong. Irish cheddar actually worked well.
I should try to make the OG too, mustard, onions and meat. That's it. Should be tasty.

Absolutely necessary for a proper "combo" or whatever the regional name is for green bell pep, white onion, sausage, pepperoni, black olive, garlic, and mozz with red sauce pizza. It's like how a Chicago hot dog needs yellow mustard, even if it's generally an inferior mustard on its own - stone ground or dijon simply doesn't work to get that specific flavor. Or, how you can't clone a big mac with romaine and cheddar instead of shredded iceberg and American cheese, even if those are worse tasting on their own.

posts.com:
>>18731754
>It's those billboards
There's an interesting story about that, actually.
As I understand it, back in 2000 there was legislation to try and limit the number of new billboards that could be built on the highways and interstates.
"New" being the operative word. Advertisers fought back by pre-emptively erecting a bunch of new billboards in hopes they'd get grandfathered in.

But after that, the bill failed and their would-be monopoly crumbled. There was a massive surplus with low demand, so advertising costs plummeted to pennies in the more rural areas of the state.

That's why you see cases where a church or a liquor store manages to buy 6 in a row. They're literally Bargain Bin Billboards.

Italian beef-Chad here. I've been to several portillos locations, as I've lived in Chicagoland throughout my entire life. Some locations have horrible staving issues and seem to be prone to getting orders incorrect. Other locations are more consistent.

Most reliable tier:
West loop
West Naperville
Oak Lawn
Schaumburg
Arlington heights

Unreliable tier:
River North
North Naperville
Bolingbrook
Niles
Summit
All the locations in Wisconsin and Indiana

Don't even bother because it's just a tourist trap/built for the sole purpose of extracting nostalgia dollars from gullible Chicagoans who fled Chicago tier:

All the locations in Arizona and California
Champaign

Just pick the right location and you can be reasonably certain that your food will come out correctly. It's sad that you gotta do this, but that's life. Despite all its issues, I still think portillos is the best chain Chicago cuisine restaurant. It's miles ahead of Al's and Buona, that's for sure.

There's only one commercially produced anymore and it's in this state. It is really strong and pungent, but the whole makes up for the sum of its parts. Everything has to be so over-the-top that they cancel each other out. Very rye bread (pumpernickel), very strong mustard, fresh red onions, and smoked spread liverwurst. Preferably with a dark beer.
Had a friend who fell asleep watching a movie while we were making it, and I gave it to him half passed out. While he was eating it he seemed fine, but then a piece fell out on his lap and he went to eat it. He immediately woke up and said what the fuck is? The individual ingredient is overpowering, but the ensemble kind of cancels each other out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18740261
You can't mess up paella. It's been destroyed beyond recognition already. By tourists who visited Valencia and thought they could make their own/better version because they had more money. So they replaced arroz redondo with inferior arroz bomba (which costs a fortune today but is for newbies) and they replaced chicken and rabbit with seafood. Even Valencians make it this way now, it's a disgrace.

There's no substitute for saffron, it's in a league of its own, together with caviar, foie gras, sweetbread, truffle and Champagne. The only way to save on it is by buying the best there is and treating it right (soak it in lukewarm water for 15 mins before you use it), you'll need to use far less of it and it costs barely more per kg than the powdered garbage they sell in supermarkets - with is mostly ground safflower and turmeric anyway. The best saffron comes from bio farms in Iran, Greece or La Mancha (Spain).

saffron is a scam. its probably just money laundering. I dont doubt its ITS OWN flavor and is very unique and notable when its /not/ there and it should be. But I'm also 100% sure that its not worth even a 10th of the hype it gets in cooking.

even truffles have more value, and I think they're kinda scammy too. at least they have the excuse of "you can't guarantee every truffle found is going to be growing in the exact same soil conditions needed to give it a strong flavor". with saffron its literally the most intensely flavored part of the plant and its still like a fart in the wind: one wiff and its gone forever.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18739526
>Will pressed purerh and white cakes continue to age after pressing
Yes they will, they are typically aged after pressing though they may age faster if loose.

>will they benefit from it?
Depends on if you prefer the aged taste or young taste. In general you should thing of the aged form as being different vs strictly being better. Fresh young sheng and well aged sheng are practically two different teas. Some really harsh or funky young puerh debatably are strait up better with aging though.

>leave them in the pantry now for a few years, will they benefit from it?
Fully aging tea takes a long time and is a slow processes in most conditions (e.g. semi aged sheng is 10ish years old, "fully" aged sheng is 20+ years old, white tea ages a bit faster). A few years in dry conditions will just make sheng a bit less green and "fresh", mellow out some of the bright floral notes of the white tea, and clear up some of the funk on shou or liu bao (probably the most useful scenario here for only aging 3 years). Starting out I would not buy tea solely to age but if you buy more tea than you drink there is nothing wrong with aging some of it. That's what I do at least.

>leave them in the pantry
Just be careful about the conditions there. You want the tea to be somewhere where it will not pick up smells. A lot of western puerh drinkers just store their tea in ziplock bags or sealed containers. The best way to store tea for aging in the west is a more complex topic and is still somewhat a mater of debate. Here are some blog posts that will put you in the right direction if you want to go down that rabbit whole.
https://teadb.org/low-barrier-puerh-storage-solutions-for-casual-puerh-drinkers/
https://teadb.org/simple-home-storage-solutions/
https://teadb.org/pumidors-101-designing-maintain-your-own-pumidor/
https://teadb.org/puerh-storage/

Japanese/Jewish/British food, its hard to decide between any of them, I like to make fusion meme meals like in shokugeki anyway, but if I had to pick one I'd say british. posts.com:
>>18742320
TV series is better and worth its own conclusion, and the movie is amazing and worth its own conclusion. I dont like the recap movies. I think the TV series is superior in sound and music and the ending of the recaps is kind of an anti climax with the changes they made to the scene where madoka talks to homura. But rebellion story is different. It's an all new soundtrack and its addictively good and completely underrated. I wish there was a falcom style remix of one for all in the soundtrack.

IT's impossible to talk about the content of the movie, but you probably heard things about its conclusion. I'll say that whatever your feelings on it, it doesn't feel warrented to say things are unsalvagably bad for fans of madoka. Madoka has constantly been someone who cares about homura and doesn't want her to suffer alone. I guess the best thing I can say about the movie if you have mixed feelings is it left things off between them in a state of equality. They have the capacity, if they chose, to have a serious conversation about their passive agressive struggle to martyr themselves for one another. But like Madoka 1-12 was a triumphant return of the powerful girl after cleansing herself of her own conciets, naiveties, and foolish ambitions, Rebellion story is about a counterattack to that. IT's literally the "strikes back" in japanese from star wars iirc. Homuras story and goal through the 12 episode anime was an abject failure. It needed to be so that madoka could shine brighter in the narrative. But are we really okay with madoka suffering the ultimate painful sacrifice if it means she gets to be free and strong? Is she? Is homura? Madoka the rebellion story is fundamentally the opposite of the narrative of 12, and the entire movie sets this up with a captivating worth watching on animation and painting grounds alone, toy like world. It's also amazing how, after dehuminizing and masculinizing herself in 12, homura recaptures her feminity in this film's theme

posts.com:
Red Lobster is good and I am TIRED OF PRETENDING IT'S NOT.

I haven't ate at Red Lobster in a couple years but it was a pretty good experience and empty due to covid. Overpriced, yes, but that's what one expects when having good seafood in a landlocked state. They literally have the best brussels sprouts somehow. They are are roasted and crispy, have a soy ginger glaze, with crispy fried onions and bacon crumbled on top. There's a lot of copycat recipes for it. I've never had brussels sprouts better in my entire life. The Ultimate Feast used to be a favorite of mine but the portions are smaller and it's like the double the price. The lobster bisque is also very high quality, which the biscuits are a nice complement with it.

>>18713841
I moved into a new house (new as in just built, not just new to me) early 2021. I did a low and slow cook of 2 racks of beef ribs in the oven, used a meat thermometer to ensure doneness. About 12 hours later came the worst stomach pain I’ve ever encountered. I could now smell traces of chemicals mixed in with my beef ribs and immediately threw the rest away.

I probably should have gone to the ER to get my stomach pumped but for every 2 hours of excruciating pain came 20 minutes of relief that tricked me into thinking it was finally over. All in all the first 24 hours were the worst but I was still on the mend 48 hours later.

When I put it together that the oven was clearly contaminated with something (I wouldn’t be surprised if it was even something like paint fumes trapped from the build process) I immediately put it on self clean mode and now I thoroughly wash every appliance or utensil prior to using it in a cook. It’s been almost 2 years and I’m afraid to try beef ribs again because I think the smell might cause my body to instinctively shut down.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I was very fat as a teenager. My cousin's kid was having a birthday party, and they were just chucking some stuff on the grill. Since there were a lot of people and they were all over the place, plates were placed out all around the house and the yard for people to grab food. Thus meant my parents couldn't really keep an eye on my consumption of food, like they usually do.

I downed 6 loaded hamburgers (as much cheese and bacon as patty), 5 bratwurst sandwiches, chips, a lot of soda, amd several slices of cake. Somehow I didn't actually feel too terrible in the moment, but just as we were leaving I started to feel queasy.

I had trouble falling asleep from the stomach ache. Eventually I did, but hours later (still in he dead of night) something inside me stirred violently and it awoke me. I had to rush naked to the bathroom and slammed my ass down on the toilet seat, where I proceeded to spew an ungodly amount of brown water from my asshole. This, combined with having consumed enough sodium earlier to have killed a horse, meant that as I sat there spewing forth a waterfall from my ass it felt like thick boiling poison was flowing through every one of my veins, a truly horrifying feeling. My stomach felt like someone was pumping it full of air to bursting point, and after that it happened.

Undigested chunks came flying out in an unholy cacophony. My body completely refused what I had crammed into it, and was just letting it all out. I spent HOURS on that toilet, not wanting to push because my asshole was incredibly sore and in tremendous pain, but needing to push because otherwise my stomach would act up and get stabbing pains. I unironically cried. After all the chunks had evacuated, I was left trying to push out a mostly clear, thick slime.

I washed my ass on the bidet (even the very gentle stream of water on my asshole stung by then) and I crawled back into bed teary eyed, feeling like what I can only asume violent anal rape by an elephant does, and passed out.

>>18713841
bad hummus...
was camping with friends and had cooked a big celebration dinner for something--Steaks, hobo pack veggies and baked potatoes on the campfire...all fresh and from scratch except for 1 thing--some hummus that LOOKED and TASTED ok, maybe a little sour, but not really OFF.
Just as we'd finished cleaning up,(quickly, as a big summer storm was rolling in,) the storm hit with a vengence--big fucking banger of a thunderstorm too.
laying down in my tent with the driving rain pelting the fly, All of a sudden, I got that feeling--you know, the tight, almost battery acid tasting tightness right behind your jaw? I knew I had seconds to get out for the inevitable technicolor yawn...
Wouldn't you know? the fucking zipper gets stuck, off track, a good 3-5 minutes of fucking around with it in the best of circumstances--and that rain is fucking coming down in BUCKETS.
PANIC....Sheer panic sets in, I can't hold my gorge back any longer...
I fucking ripped the tent door open at the zipper and stumbled out into the now hammering rain, puking all that excellent dinner we'd just eaten in all directions as I staggered through the muddy forest to get further away from the tent, so I didn't have a pool of vomit sitting right outside of it. I spent the next 15 minutes on all fours, purging my entire being until I could do nothing but dry heave with sheets of water coming down all around me...
I was fine in the morning, and was able to fix the tent zipper so that it would NEVER LOCK UP ON ME AGAIN...but that had to be the worst.
Only one almost as bad was burning through half a case of little kings playing the "minute game"I made good friends with the snails that night as I crawled around in the dewy grass under the full moon...good times.
btw, when I checked that Godforsaken CURSED HUMMUS the next morning, it was actually bubbling--so I know that was the culprit.
I still like hummus though, even if I always give it the hairy-eyeball if it's store-bought.

Specifically seven is italoamerican, yes, but we just eat any ol' fish and in no specific number. How the fish is prepared and which fish it is varies family to family and/or by simple availability/what looks good at the market.
Poles do it, too, though with a bit more rigidity in menu, and even call the meal by the same name we do, la vigilia IE the vigil. They just swap the V for a W cuz they're silly, silly Poles.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18732235
We had all kinds of shit, chicken, ham, sausages, blood sausage, sauerkraut, potatoes, štruklji (pic related), etc. A general feast. It's worth noting that while some parts of Slovenia are heavily influenced by Italy, the majority of the country is influenced a lot more by Austria. I'm guessing they don't do this. If they do then I'm gonna be thoroughly confused.
Also I said we're arguably central european because during geography in middle and high school we were taught that, but if you asked the personal opinion of geography teachers a third would probably tell you we're central, a third would tell you we're south eastern and a third would tell you they have no fucking idea. We're in a weird place geographically and culturally.

>>18737346
Nope. You would think so. It's heavily salted lamb meat, so you have to soak it in water for 24-36 hours and then you steam it for 3-5 hours until it's fork tender. You either put some wooden sticks or almond potatoes in the bottom of the pan for the steaming. It renders out an amazing fatty stock which you can use for sauce and if you do the potato version they will still be firm even though they have been boiled for 3-5 hours due to the salt and fat.

At the end you put them in the oven for 10 mins just to get a bit of color. The Rutabaga and carrot mash is sweet and creamy, balancing out the fatty, salty meat. On the side you have a shot of akevit to help against the fat.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Polish fagg here, me and my family cooked pretty much the usual you see in Poland:
>Croquettes (2 types, one with sauerkraut and mushrooms, the other with eggs)
>Pierogies (sauerkraut with mushrooms and russian ones with potatoes and cottage cheese)
>Beetroot soup with "uszka" (these are basically mini pierogies with mushroom and sauerkraut filing that are boiled)
>Some kind of fish (don't remember which one it was, in the past it used to be carp because my grandfather really liked it)
>"Paszteciki", sauerkraut filled dough balls, baked in the oven with some nigella seeds on top. I have no clue why my mom calls them like this since they don't include any meat, but not gonna complain since they taste great
>leftover sauerkraut as a side
>bunch of spiced fries made from leftover potatoes
>Couple of cakes and cookies, most of them based around poppy seeds (most of them were too sweet for me, so I gave it a pass)

We also made bunch of food for us after Christmas Eve to eat with leftovers (some pork belly, ribs, chuck, salads, etc.). I really wanted to make some mulled wine or eggnog, but we didn't find much time, plus considering all the gifts and shit we kinda run out of budget. Overall had a great time.

posts.sub: How to make the best frozen pizza thread
posts.com: Happy holidays! I've come to share my frozen pizza knowledge and enlighten anonymous land. To start, I prefer Red Baron, Newman's Own, and a couple others. I try to get the crust thin and crispy, as I want the crust to come out as crispy as possible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: why does the chicken bag have “no antibiotics ever”, are americans afraid of antibiotics?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Heat the oven to 500 and put the frozen pizza in for approximately 5 minutes. It should come out looking like this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Now for the good stuff. I live in Michigan right next to a cloverleaf pizzeria. I buy their cups of pizza sauce and stock up. Add 1 cup of pizza sauce directly over the pizza.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Now add the seasoning. I put a dash of rosemary, oregano, thyme, and plenty of crushed red pepper flakes for spice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Add the grilled chicken (I added a pinch of salt) and jalapeños.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I always make sure to get Whole milk mozzarella cheese. I add the cheese on top last. Put this back in the oven for 5 ~6 minutes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: And there you have it. A crispy crust, tons of sauce and cheese with flavor and spice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: If anyone has other recommendations and tips, post 'em.

here's full recipe as promised:

. 750 grams for 4 people. fresh acnhovis or sardines, small-ish size, like you can eat fully in 3 bites tops
. . without head or fish-bones (here you can ask the women on the fish section to cut them like that for you, or do it yourself at home)

. wash them and put the in a bowl covered with the following
. . half a glass of water
. . half glass of wine vinegar (can use the regular one or modena doesn't matter)
. . salt, chopped garlig, oregano
. . . cover the sardines in the bowl with this mix for 1h (minimum) or 1 day (optimal) (you can put them in the fridge no problemo)
. drain the sardines a bit, cover in all purpose flour and fry them until golden color
. . . das le it
. . . . (pic is some random pic that resembles the final result)

Steel wool to scrub gunk. Apply very thin coat of high smoke point oil then put pan in 500 degree oven for 20ish minutes. Cool enough so oil doesn't smoke, repeat until you question your sanity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18739179
You're in luck, there's no restoration needed for that pan, just clean whatever is stuck in it and start using grammy's pan. Pour in a cup of water and bring it to a simmer, then stir around the bottom with a wooden spoon or spatula until that crud has come off, and pour it all out. Then wipe it down with a paper towel, put it back on the stovetop to dry, and once it's warm apply a light coat of oil and you're done.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18739817
Among coffee making methods pods are in the bottom 3, along with instant and cheap filter coffee machines. They're better than instant, and like on par with basic filter coffee.
If you want to upgrade the first thing you're gonna want is a grinder, grinding beans fresh makes a big difference and also opens you up to specialty coffee shops, which often sell only beans. The usual entry level recommendation for a grinder is the 1zpresso q2, there's also the kingrinder k4 (more espresso focused) and k6 (more of an all rounder). All of these cost $100 or more, but the grinder is often the most expensive and most often used bit of coffee kit you're gonna own.
You're also gonna want scales (there's a decent chink one you can get for $15, I think the OP pasta mentions it), a thermometer if you're gonna be brewing medium or darker roasts (you don't want to use boiling water for dark roasts) and pick what brewing method you want
>aeropress
A plastic tube that you brew coffee in and push it through a filter with a plunger. About $30 and hard to fuck up.
>pourover
The most popular pourover brewer is the hario v60. Ranges from $10 (plastic) to $20 (glass or ceramic). Pourovers can be great but require a bit of skill that you'll need to learn. Also it's very nice to have a gooseneck pouring kettle for them (although not essential), which drives up the cost.
>french press
Usually about $20 or more, hard to fuck up like the aeropress, but with the downside of having worse filtering and the upside of making bigger batches of coffee
>moka pot
Makes strong espresso-ish coffee, decent ones are $30 for very small ones and it goes up from there. Some people really like them, some people really hate them. The warcrime that is the OP webm is using a moka pot (just don't do what that guy does for the love of god).
>espresso
Espresso is expensive and a lot of fuss, even a lot of coffee enthusiasts don't bother with it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18740661
the 7 gram rule comes from the Italian Coffe Institute rules for making espresso. Literally read the Wikipedia page about espresso.

the 2:1 extraction ratio is a rule of thumb that should be a starting point for making espresso. Go to YouTube and watch Whole Latte Love's videos about "dialing in" espresso. Hoffmeme probably has a good video, too, but I get distracted by his fetal alcohol syndrome face under his massive eyeglasses.

adjusting the brew ratio to balance the flavors is a common technique. it's generally accepted that during extraction you get acids & oils first, then sugars, and finally bitter compounds. So if your espresso is too sour, more extraction can help. If your espresso is too bitter, less extraction is needed. You can change boiler temperature, grind size, dose size, extraction pressure, and brew ratio to affect the extraction. Each variable has its own benefits and consequences.

Finally, understand that ristretto and longo shots exist as a means to fix coffee that give very bitter or very sour espresso.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18741743
the coffee astrada article on grinding finer has been the most relevant thing post ITT with respect to grinder selection. That said, Gagne also acknowledges that the need for reducing the height of the fines peak in your grind's PSD is still debated. Here's what I took from the article:

>reducing the proportion of fines can increase flow at a given grinder setting and extraction condition
>to restore flow to your target (whatever you had with the larger fines proportion) you can now grind even finer
>grinding even finer at the same extraction condition should lead to higher extraction yield in the same amount of time
>but achieving low fines peak is still technically difficult and therefore expensive
>at the end of the day, reducing fines peak may not lead to better tasting coffee, just different tasting coffee

based on everything I've seen & read from Rao, Hoffmeme, and now Gagne, it seems like I should keep playing with my current setup and delay moving into next-tier grinders until the science is better understood.

I got into espresso because it's a rich, complex beverage. Increasing "clarity" sounds like you're making watery espresso and telling yourself it's good because you spent a lot of money "reducing fines" to make espresso that tastes like coffee from your V60. Just go back to your manual Mr Coffee if that's what you like. It's not a contest, but my coffee > your coffee.

posts.com: Okay Anons this sourdough starter has been doing it's thing for a week how do I test it if it's ready. Because it doesn't look like it has though major wholes I see with other YouTubers. However this could be for the fact that I use all purpose flour instead of the other types, can this still work? Is it possible with all purpose flour? Why doesn't look like cheese holes? And how to test if it's ready? (Because I heard it has to pass the floating water test)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>how do I test it if it's ready
feed it. if it doubles, then it's ready.

yes, it's possible to make sourdough starter with all purpose flour. it's easier to get it started with less-processed flour, but you can feed an established starter with whatever kind of wheat flour you want.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Water is going to have more of an effect than the water in my experience.
Municipal water in my area is pretty chlorinated, and will straight up kill my starter if I use it in a couple feeds. (Always keep a backup jar in the fridge and/or some dried paste in the freezer)
A run through a pitcher style filter or a day sitting on the counter in an open container clears out the chlorine enough to use.
If you are just getting started maybe use some bottled or distilled water at first just to be sure you are not killing your critters.
Other than that yeah, just keep dumping and feeding till it’s ready, the bubbles and the smell will let you know.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18740892
Thanks Anons, but how do I know how many bubbles are like enough, should it look like picrel? Also what are the types of tests that assure the starter is ready? I heard that if it flats on water that means it's ready.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Your water to flour ratio looks much heavier on the water than the picture you posted, for that picture to have bubbles like that it’s a much thicker mixture to sustain the structure.
To check if it’s ready to use:
Don’t stir first, you want to get rid of the beer if there is any on top.
Dump half.
Put in a little bit of water
Stir
Sprinkle in flour slowly while stirring to get to the point where it crosses from liquid to thin dough, roughly when the jar starts to turn with your stirring but not to the point where the starter pulling away from the sides of the jar.
Scrape down the stuff from the edge of the jar.
Stick a rubber band or hair tie around the jar at the level of the starter stuff so you can see how much it raises
Walk away for two hours
Come back, if it’s at or near the rubber band level still, dump and feed a few more days
If it has grown over the rubber band a decent amount, even not doubled, make a small loaf with it to see where it’s at and feed the stuff left in the jar, it will just get better with time.
Our current starter is from 2019 and it’s been a bumpy ride.
Once it’s established, make backups.

For about 200 grams of cooked chickpeas
2 tablespoons of olive oil
3 tablespoons of butter
Oregano
Parsley
Garlic, use dried garlic as it will stand higher heat
Cayenne or your favorite hot sauce
Black pepper
Half a spoon of mustard
One tablespoon of peanut butter
Sesame oil to taste

>>18739559
Alcohol taxes make malt liquor pointless in Australia and I doubt people would like it anyway even if it was viable. Reason is there's an alcohol tax which is based around alcohol volume that would make malt liquor too expensive for people to bother buying.
Instead of cheep beer, in Australia we use cask wine because there's a different tax on wine that becomes much lower than beer when buying cheap cask wine. You can get a 4L box of wine with ~30 standard drinks for $9 AUD but the cheapest ratshit beers with an equivalent alcohol level would cost 5 times as much. If you don't like wine buy want cheaper options then you just go buy large bottles of gin or vodka & mix it, or Mercury Cider where you can get cans with double the alcohol most beers contain without costing too much more.

If a meal is truly superb, I will often request to speak to the chef. Usually, it's no problem and they are appreciative that their craft and labour has been enjoyed.

However, there was one experience that left me rather shaken and made me consider if I should ever do it again. I travel most days of the week for work. We set up alot of IT stuff for hospitals. One day I was travelling to somewhere in Kentucky. I was excited to go because 1.) I had never been and 2.) I was excited to try the local fare and learn more about what people ate there. We got in late and really didn't have time to eat anywhere particularly locale the first night, but after arriving to work the next day we were recommended to eat at a place called "Randy's Kountry Kitchen". I was a little hesitant because the name sounded foreboding, but I trusted our advice and we headed out for lunch.

I normally eat alone as I tend to take my time, but this time I rode along with some new coworkers. We were seated in a what appeared to be a very rundown shack. There were flies everywhere and our checkered tablecloth was sticky. The waitress was very rude and just asked "What y'all want?" I didn't have time to peruse the menu, which just happened to be a piece of printer paper listing their items so I informed her I would need a few minutes. My coworkers immediately started drinking. They just got burgers. I thought that was foolish and opted to get their special: A chicken fried steak with pepper gravy. I was floored. It was fried just right and the gravy was smooth and creamy. My coworkers at this point were beginning to get more and more inebriated, even though it was a lunch break and I began to wonder how we were going to get back. As, I stated I usually take my time with my food. My coworkers began to tease and berate my eating habits. One said "I ate like a faggot" to which I found very insulting. I wanted to savor every bite and took my time. Anyways onto "my compliments

civil
adjective
civ·il ˈsi-vəl
1
a
: of or relating to citizens
civil duties
b
: of or relating to the state or its citizenry
civil strife


Civil War

In the United States, "Civil War" is the most common term for the conflict and has been used by the overwhelming majority of reference books, scholarly journals, dictionaries, encyclopedias, popular histories, and mass media in the United States since the early 20th century.[1] The National Park Service, the government organization entrusted by the US Congress to preserve the battlefields of the war, uses this term.[2] Writings of prominent men such as Jefferson Davis, Robert E. Lee,[3] Ulysses S. Grant, William Tecumseh Sherman, P. G. T. Beauregard, Nathan Bedford Forrest, and Judah P. Benjamin used the term "Civil War" during the conflict.[citation needed] Abraham Lincoln used it on multiple occasions.[4][5][6] In 1862, the US Supreme Court used the terms "the present civil war between the United States and the so called Confederate States" and "the civil war such as that now waged between the Northern and Southern States."[7]

English-language historians[8][9][10] outside the United States usually refer to the conflict as the "American Civil War". Such variations are also used in the United States if the war might otherwise be confused with another civil war such as the English Civil War, the Russian Civil War, or the Spanish Civil War.

>>18739674
Mexican coke is still the original coca-cola recipe. It contains cane sugar and real cola syrup. The shit they sell in America uses artificial flavoring and hfcs.
The "New Coke" thing in '85 was a scam. It was never meant to be an actual replacement. They pulled regular Coca-Cola off the shelves just long enough for people to forget what Coca-Cola actually tasted like. They changed the ingredients - replacing the syrup and sugar with chemicals and hcfs - and then brought "Original" Coca-Cola back to market. It was a classic bait and switch.
If you want real Coca-Cola, the only option is the 355ml bottles of Mexican coke.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18739674
it's a combination of factors. The primary one that most people will notice would be carbination. Bottles, cans, glass, they all hold carbination at different rates. Bottles tend to be the best for holding carbination but corporate has realized they can get away with less so its not a guarentee. Carbination is also dependent upon the supply of co2 gas. When it gets pricier, they cut it back and your soda tasts flatter regardless of what its in and how old it is. When I see soda on sale, I usually dont buy it because that usually indicates that the containers are old. The older the container, the higher chance for more off gassing, which means the less carbinated it is. Shipments being left out in the sun, or being exposed to dramatic temperature shifts can also cause carbinaization loss. lots of people dont realize but plastic is permeable, and it breaks down over time as well. Cans use to be the go to for a good soda but theyve slowly been made thinner and thinner, and to compensate for that they started lining the cans with a kind of chemical plastic.

Moving on, other things can effect the taste. What kind of sugar or sugar substitute used can vary throughout the season, and if you arent a heavy drinker/smoker/degenerate then you might pick up on the particulars of the different serups beingt used. This is something a non-gourmand wont understand. Temperature is also important. Soda tastes different hot/cold or with ice.

Also keep in mind that how something tastes is directly related to the state of your taste buds and nose. If you are sick or have a stuffy nose, the taste will be different. If you consume certain foods, the taste will be different. You know how people say 'dont drink orange juice and then brush your teeth'? The same applies with soda. I once ate some really rich Orange chicken and then tried to have a cola and the cola tasted like motor oil.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I remember middle school health class covering the food pyramid and how even as a child it felt sketchy at best. It's turned upside its head in so many ways. Even going by its min serving recommendations results in ~2100 calories a day. 2s milk (488g, 293cal) + 2s beef steak (170g, 428cal) + 3s mixed veg (30oz, 546cal) + 2s mixed fruit (324g, 194cal) + 6s grain (174g, 660cal) = 2121cal.
It's a categorical simplification that prioritizes ease of sorting over nutritional impact. Consider the analogy: An exercise pyramid that categorizes exercises by dumbbell, barbell, machine, no weights / body weight, etc.. It's stupid.

The truest statement on food health is, and always has been, "Eat a well balanced diet in moderation."
What makes a diet balanced? Depends more on your body than anything else. Sometimes your body needs more of something or doesn't need as much of something. That need, or lack thereof, could be short-, medium-, or long-term.
If your body is low on an essential nutrient (protein, vitamin, acids, etc..) then eat more foods that contribute to that, preferably while keeping your avg caloric intake approximately constant.
If you want to lose weight you don't even have to change the balance of your diet. Just literally eat less of the same diet. Although, if your protein intake would drop too much I recommend altering the diet a bit to prevent that. That and regular exercise will help reducing your muscle loss as you lose weight.

Also for fucks sake, stop thinking of nutrition as something that has to be met every day. It's a rolling average over days, if not weeks. You don't need some crazy diet that has all of your essentials every day. Some days you get more of this and less or none of that. It's all about averages over time. If you really need breakpoints, use 3d and 7d averages.
When I wanted to lose weight I lost an avg of 2 lbs/wk over 4 months even though some days I had ~2500cal because I kept my avg daily intake under my target ~1500cal.

The red pill is vegetables don't taste bad and are actually enjoyable if you learn how to cook them right. Next year I want to try something with a strong flavour, I’ll probably pick something from Southern Italy because they experiment the most with flavours.

I still have to try at home: Moschella Apple and cinnamon, Martesana traditional and the Fiasconaro saffron and citrus fruits.

Panettone, on the other hand, is the gentleman’s choice because it’s so rich and smells like heaven, there are flavours hidden in the bites, you can find the raisin and then a piece of candied orange in the next one, or both, and the same goes for other flavours, also the glaze or “topping”
some style of panettone have makes sure that you won’t get bored at all while eating the slice, and the airy interior makes up for a moist and soft experience.

In other words, pandoro is for kids who loves simpler things, panettone is for grown ups.

>>18731581
>We shouldn't mess with the classic panettone – the idea that everything has to be new saddens me
>Panettone has been ruined by poor variations including prosecco, salted caramel, and savoury cheese flavours

>There are two things about the wave of adulterated panettones – featuring novelty flavours including everything from tiramisu to peach bellini and even parmesan and black pepper – that I strongly resent. The classic recipe and its original ingredients – flour, butter, raisins and candied citrus among them – were intended to make the cake last for some time. It was created to transport easily and takes days to make, for the dough to prove, but can last for weeks. It is pure.

>Modern technology, which enables producers to pump just about anything into panettone, has led to an ill-formed cake with an ingredients list packed with additives that are far from conducive to your health.

>Secondly, the idea that everything has to be new, or reinvented with new flavours, saddens me. Of course food – and our attitude towards it – changes through the ages, but just sometimes in life we ought to just stop and enjoy something that has been around for centuries. If something still excites our senses and makes our heart sing after so long, we ought to ask the question why.

>Panettone has been a Christmas tradition my whole life. We didn’t have much money when I was growing up and we didn’t have an oven capable of making one, but we would buy one – it was our treat, a Christmas cake only sold at Christmas time. I loved the airy texture, the generous amount of raisins and chunks of candied peel studded throughout, and would happily pick off the sugar crystals from the top to eat, to the annoyance of my mother. She insisted there had to be enough left for everyone to enjoy.

posts.com:
Cakettone recipe:

>2 eggs
>1/2 cup sugar
>1 1/2 cup flour
>1/4 cup oil
>1/4 cup milk
>1/2 cup raisins
>1/2 cup candied peel
>1 TBSP panettone extract
>1 TBSP cake yeast
>1 cup cream
Icing
>1 cup icing sugar
>1 1/2 TBSP milk
>fruits to decorate

Beat eggs, and sugar until frothy. Add oil, milk and cream and beat. Add flour little at the time and mix. Add extract and cake levener and mix. Add ruits and mix. Cook in buttered and flour cake tin until done. Let cool, add icing, add fruit to decorate.

posts.com:
Here is the Moschella panettone with apple and cinnamon.

Low Milanese type, it is very soft to the touch and the blade of the knife sinks very easily.

The scent is that of cinnamon, it feels good, when cut there is a nice straw yellow color and you can see the candied apple cut into pieces of irregular size and present in limited quantities, I would have liked more. Quite regular but not very developed honeycomb, clearly visible vanilla beans.

The dough is soft and moist, it comes off easily but remains compact, it is not very elastic and when bitten it does not have that spectacular lightness that you find in Renato Bosco's panettone, but it almost seems to have the impression that the dough has not been fully cooked.

Is it a defect of this particular panettone or a choice?

However the taste is good and it is pleasant to eat, it is not demanding, but to my taste something more could have been done to give an extra boost to the taste, perhaps adding raisins.

The sweetness is contained, the butter and vanilla flavor is balanced.

Considering the increases, at €35 per kg the value for money is honest.

A good panettone but with some flaws.

Rating 7½/10

Here's mine OP, inb4 I get mogged for putting corn in my chili.

INGREDIENTS:

FRESH
5-6lb of ground beef
1 ½ large onions
4 large bell peppers

CANNED
3 28oz cans of whole peeled San Marzano tomatoes
2 14oz cans of dark red kidney beans
1 14oz can of whole kernel corn
1 7oz can of chipotle peppers

WET INGREDIENTS
2 tbsp of honey
1 tbsp mustard
2 tsp Worcestershire
2 tsp soy sauce
2 tsp fish sauce
fat/oil for frying

SPICES
5 tbsps. chili powder
Habanero/cayenne powder
1 tbsp paprika
1 tbsp cumin
1 tbsp Chicken Bullion
½ tsp garlic powder

OPTIONAL GARNISHES
Sour cream
Crackers, corn chips, tortilla chips
Avocado
Chives or parsley
Shredded Cheese


Also why yes the chicken bullion I use is indeed Knorr™ brand
